Description: Terracotta figure plaque of Apis-bull in a shrine. The shrine has a plain pediment with a curved upper edge and a central acroterial ornament; it is supported by two slender columns with stylized capitals. Within, the bull stands to the right, its head facing the front, with a solar disc between the horns. The back is plain. Only upper part of the shrine is preserved. Hollow, from a two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt with a darker brown surface in places. Traces of a white dressing, mostly on the front; some areas at the edges of the bull are painted red-brown.
Curator's comments: Published in volume on Apis bull (Kater-Sibbes and Vermaseren 1975, fig. 130). Kater-Sibbes, G.J.F., Vermaseren, M.J. 1975, Apis I. The Monuments of the Hellenistic-Roman Period from Egypt; II. Monuments from Outside Egypt, Leiden.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (C614)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.212) (Phase 1)
Condition: Three of its legs have lost their lower parts, but the right hind leg is almost complete: whatever plinth it had is now lost, but is restored in plaster.
